articles.description:
Added: support an experimental template for YouTube feed üì∫ Demo | Source

Aggregate content from any YouTube channel rss url https://www.youtube.com/feeds/videos.xml?channel_id=<replace_with_channel_id>
Videos are embedded via iframe and loading accelerated by youtube-lite-embed
Ads are reduced thanks to YouTube's policy for embedded videos üôÉ
Works on mobile devices with butter smooth horizontal scroll.
Caveat: the template works only with YouTube content. You cannot mix textual RSS feed or other video sources such as Vimeo.
Changed: Default HTML template meta tag adjusted to match convention
Changed: sources in template data is now ordered by last update timestamp (as opposed to alphabetical)
Thank you @PiyushLosalka
articles.title: v1.11.0

sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine ‚Äî For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cassidy Williams)
articles.description: There are two strategies for incrementally building websites that are growing in popularity: Incremental Static Regeneration and Distributed Persistent Rendering. What‚Äôs the difference? Let‚Äôs figure it out.
articles.title: ISR vs DPR: Big Words, Quick Explanation

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Zara Cooper)
articles.description: In this article, you‚Äôll get to see some pretty groundbreaking things you can achieve with modern JavaScript grids and discover new ways to augment a data grid to make it engaging, responsive, and accessible. All this will be illustrated using Kendo UI Data Grids and their features.
articles.title: You Can Do That With A JavaScript Data Grid?

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: Too often dealing with filters can be frustrating. Let‚Äôs get them right. That means never freeze the UI on a single input, provide text input fallback and never auto-scroll users on a single input. Here‚Äôs why.
articles.title: Frustrating Design Patterns: Broken Filters

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Michelle Barker)
articles.description: In JavaScript, attaching an event listener to constantly fire a callback on scroll can be performance-intensive. But there is a better way with Intersection Observer.
articles.title: Building A Dynamic Header With Intersection Observer

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Facundo Giuliani)
articles.description: In this article, we‚Äôre taking a closer look at different approaches and strategies on how we can migrate a web application that uses jQuery framework, and start using one of the coolest React frameworks in the market: Next.js.
articles.title: How To Migrate From jQuery To Next.js

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Adrian Bece)
articles.description: CSS refactoring is not an easy task ‚Äî it needs to be done in a way that doesn't create problems. First we need to analyze the existing codebase, audit CSS codebase health, discover weaknesses, agree on the approach, and convince management to invest time and resources into the process.
articles.title: Refactoring CSS: Introduction (Part 1)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Todd Libby)
articles.description: Accessibility is often overlooked or bolted on to the end of a project. Let‚Äôs figure out how to implement and advocate for accessibility from the inception of a project to the release or handoff and beyond.
articles.title: Making A Strong Case For Accessibility

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Uma Victor)
articles.description: Even though Vue.js claims to have an approachable minimalist framework that can be incrementally adaptable, it can be a little bit overwhelming when starting as a Vue.js newbie. In this article, we‚Äôre looking at ways to make writing Vue.js a breeze.
articles.title: Tools And Practices To Speed Up The Vue.js Development Process

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Emiliano Cicero)
articles.description: Interactive Components in Figma allows designers to create a component with states (hover, active, clicked, focus) and make it interactive so that every copy of the component will inherit those same interactions by default. Let‚Äôs explore how it can reduce the time and effort needed to create interactions for your mock-ups.
articles.title: An Introduction To Figma Interactive Components

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Emmanuel Tissera)
articles.description: There is an array of Headless CMSes out there. In this article, we delve into headless CMS features to satisfy your content editors, marketers and yourself as a developer. For the experience headless practitioner, this could be a checklist to see what‚Äôs new out there. For those starting out on their headless journey, this could be a guide on what to look for.
articles.title: How To Choose A Headless CMS

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ahmad Shadeed)
articles.description: In this article, Ahmad Shadeed explains what HSL is, how to use it, and shares some of the useful use-cases and examples that you can use right away in your current projects.
articles.title: Using HSL Colors In CSS

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Andriy Zapisotskyi)
articles.description: With so many tools and approaches, email still has quite a few pain points, both for developers and email marketers. Email is difficult because it has too many aspects to set and a few instances with no common rules to follow.
articles.title: Email Testing Flow As It Should Be

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Ramona Schwering)
articles.description: When writing front-end tests, you‚Äôll find a lot of pitfalls along the way. Let‚Äôs explore common mistakes developers make, and how to avoid them. Testing doesn‚Äôt need to be painful, after all.
articles.title: It‚Äôs A (Front-End Testing) Trap! Six Common Testing Pitfalls And How To Solve Them

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Surma)
articles.description: The web is single-threaded. This makes it increasingly hard to write smooth and responsive apps. Workers have a bad rep, but can be an important and useful tool in any web developer's toolbelt for these kinds of problems. Let‚Äôs get up to speed on Workers on the Web!
articles.title: The State Of Web Workers In 2021

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Let‚Äôs welcome July with some fresh desktop wallpapers. Designed by artists and designers from around the world, they are available with and without a calendar. Enjoy!
articles.title: The Many Shades Of July (2021 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (√Åtila Fassina)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Mark Lankmilier)

articles.title: How To Run A UX Audit For A Major EdTech Platform (Case Study)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Josh Singer)
articles.description: In the dynamic and unpredictable environments in which we work, even the most carefully crafted solutions can have a short shelf life. When we accept that our work is impermanent and our problem-solving abilities are limited, our goal can shift from delivering full solutions to developing tools that empower our users to adaptively design for themselves.

And we have new ones coming up, and we‚Äôd like to kindly welcome you to join in.

In order for voice user interfaces to really break through, feedback to the user must be visual, not auditive.

articles.author: Aya Bouchiha
articles.description:
Hi,  this #day-33,  we are going to discuss 5 useful input attributes.
this attribute is almost used with a title attribute that describes the input's pattern, its role is to specify a valid JavaScript regular expression that the input field's value is checked against when the form is submitted. It works with the following input types: (text, email, tel, password, search, url, date).
more details
<form>
    <input
        type="text"
        placeholder="full name..."
        pattern="[A-z]{8,16}"
        title="the full name should be between 4 and 15 letters"
    />
    <input type="submit" />
</form>

Output:

maxlength is an input attribute that specifies the maximum length of characters allowed in an input field. And when the length of the input's value is equal to the maxlength, the ‚Ä¶
articles.title: 5 useful Input Attributes

articles.author: Stanley Lim
articles.description:
As a long-time Spotify user, I love the end-of-year stats that Spotify surfaces each year. If you‚Äôre like me, you probably hate waiting till the end of each year just to see your top songs, artists, and genres.
This is why I developed Spottr, a progressive web app that satisfies that curiosity!

Spottr is a PWA developed to surface your Spotify listening habits year-round rather than at the end of each year.
The first main reason as stated above was the burning desire I had to know about how my listening habits have changed over time.
The second reason was to rewrite this project again from scratch using Angular 10, Tailwind CSS, and push my design and front-end development skills. My first iteration was started back in 2018 with Angular 6, but I scrapped that since the project was not pla‚Ä¶
articles.title: üéâ Introducing Spottr - Your Spotify Stats Year-Round

I've been wondering for a while about how to start this article, but I think I'll just jump into it.
Unity - the budding game developer's favorite tool
Muse Headband 2014 - a headband that people normally use to meditate, together with the Muse App
MuseLab - software that acted as a data middleman between the headband and unity
Terminal of choice - I used iTerm. I like iTerm.
Now, I'll let you in on something, I had no clue how I was gonna pull this off. I initially wanted to just make a simple game, but my tutor said 
It was not.
Muse had very little support (at the time) for connecting the headband to neither PC or Mac. The only thing that Muse offered me was their API (MuseLab) that helps you visualise your brainwaves and send the data further on to a set IP through UDP packets, which, ‚Ä¶
articles.title: How I wrote a Brain-Computer Interface Game with 0 knowledge - PsyBreaker

articles.author: Renan Proen√ßa
articles.description:
Overview



In this chapter, i'll walk you through the installation, configuration and how to use Redis in a simple way. In this process, i'll use Docker to create a container with the Redis image.
Docker
In this first step, you need to install Docker on your machine by following the steps below.
1.Update Software Repositories:
sudo apt-get update
2.Install some prerequisite packages that let apt use packages over HTTPS:
sudo apt install apt-transport-https ca-certificates curl software-properties-common
3.So, add GPG Key to repository Docker on your SO:
curl -fsSL https://download.docker.com/linux/ubuntu/gpg | sudo apt-key add -
4.Add the repository Docker to fonts of the APT:
sudo add-apt-repository "deb [arch=amd64] https://download.docker.com/linux/ubuntu focal stable"
5.Again:
sudo ap‚Ä¶
articles.title: Adding Redis easily with Docker

================Java OOP Concepts==========
What is OOP?
OOP Stands for Object-Oriented Programming.Object-Oriented Programming is paradigm that provides many concepts,such as inheritance,polymorphism etc.It simplifies software development and maintenance by providing some concepts.
What are the OOPs Concepts?
There are,

Java Is an Object-Oriented Programming language.Everything in Java is associated with class and objects,along with it's attributes and methods.Classes and Objects are two main aspects of object-oriented programming.
Let us consider the above oop concepts one by one..
Objects=> Any Entity that has state and behaviour is known as a object.Examples are Chair,Pen,Table etc.
Class=> Class is a Collection of objects.It is a Logical Entity.So, Class is a Definition of object,tem‚Ä¶

articles.author: Daniel Lemire
articles.description: When designing an index, a database or a search engine, you frequently need to compute the union of two sorted sets. When I am not using fancy low-level instructions, I have most commonly computed the union of two sorted sets using the following approach: v1 = first value in input 1 v2 = first value ‚Ä¶ Continue reading Faster sorted array unions by reducing branches
articles.title: Faster sorted array unions by reducing branches

articles.description: We use CRISPR, a state-of-the-art gene editing technique, to edit the genes of live human patients in a clinical trials. A clinical trial has begun regarding an HIV vaccine. If you choose to forgo meat to fight climate change, you may lower your individual‚Äôs lifetime warming contribution by 2 to 4%. articles.author: Daniel Lemire
articles.description: JSON is the de facto standard for exchanging data on the Internet. It is relatively simple text format inspired by JavaScript. I say ‚Äúrelatively simple‚Äù because you can read and understand the entire JSON specification in minutes. Though JSON is a concise format, it is also better used over a slow network in compressed mode. ‚Ä¶ Continue reading Compressing JSON: gzip vs zstd
articles.title: Compressing JSON: gzip vs zstd

articles.author: Daniel Lemire
articles.description: Reportedly, half of us own a smartphone. It is often reported that women or visible minority earn less money. However, ugly people are doing comparatively even more poorly.
